answer_html: We used the fact that \(\ln 1 = 0\) above.
answer_latex: We used the fact that $\ln 1 = 0$ above.
hints_html: Use partial fractions. As a first step you need to factor the denominator.
hints_latex:
Use partial fractions. As a first step you need to factor the
denominator.
hints_raw: Use partial fractions. As a first step you need to factor the denominator.
question: 3 (b)
sols_html:
One way to evaluate \(\int_0^1 \frac{1}{x^2 - 5x + 6} dx\) is to use partial fractions.

We note that \(x^2 - 5x + 6 = (x-2)(x-3)\), and so we decompose the fraction into:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{(x-2)(x-3)} = \frac{A}{x-2} + \frac{B}{x-3}\end{aligned}\]

which becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1 = A(x-3) + B(x-2)\end{aligned}\]

after multiplying through by the common denominator of \((x-2)(x-3)\). If we expand the equation out and find the coefficients of the respective powers of x then:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 0x + 1 = (A+B)x + (-3A - 2B)\end{aligned}\]

  • From matching the \(x\) coefficients, \(A + B = 0\) so \(A = -B\).

  • From matching the constant coefficients, \(-3A - 2B = 1\) which becomes \(-3(-B) - 2B = 1\) in using the relation above.

This tells us that \(B = 1\) and therefore \(A = -1\).

The integral is easy to evaluate now:

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^1 \frac{1}{x^2 - 5x + 6} dx &= \int_0^1 (\frac{1}{x-3} - \frac{1}{x-2}) dx \\ &= [\ln|x-3| - \ln|x-2|]|_0^1 \\ &= (\ln 2 - \ln 1) - (\ln 3 - \ln 2) \\ &= 2 \ln 2 - \ln 3\end{aligned}\]

We used the fact that \(\ln 1 = 0\) above.
sols_latex:
One way to evaluate $\int_0^1 \frac{1}{x^2 - 5x + 6} dx$ is to use
partial fractions.

We note that $x^2 - 5x + 6 = (x-2)(x-3)$, and so we decompose the
fraction into:

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{(x-2)(x-3)} = \frac{A}{x-2} + \frac{B}{x-3}
\end{align*} which becomes

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
1 = A(x-3) + B(x-2)
\end{align*} after multiplying through by the common
denominator of $(x-2)(x-3)$. If we expand the equation out and find the
coefficients of the respective powers of x then:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
0x + 1 = (A+B)x + (-3A - 2B)
\end{align*}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  From matching the $x$ coefficients, $A + B = 0$ so $A = -B$.
\item
  From matching the constant coefficients, $-3A - 2B = 1$ which becomes
  $-3(-B) - 2B = 1$ in using the relation above.
\end{itemize}

This tells us that $B = 1$ and therefore $A = -1$.

The integral is easy to evaluate now:

\begin{align*}
\int_0^1 \frac{1}{x^2 - 5x + 6} dx &= \int_0^1 (\frac{1}{x-3} - \frac{1}{x-2}) dx \\
&= [\ln|x-3| - \ln|x-2|]|_0^1 \\
&= (\ln 2 - \ln 1) - (\ln 3 - \ln 2) \\
&= 2 \ln 2 - \ln 3
\end{align*}

We used the fact that $\ln 1 = 0$ above.
sols_raw:
One way to evaluate <math>\int_0^1 \frac{1}{x^2 - 5x + 6} dx</math> is to use partial fractions.

We note that <math>x^2 - 5x + 6 = (x-2)(x-3)</math>, and so we decompose the fraction into:

:<math>\frac{1}{(x-2)(x-3)} = \frac{A}{x-2} + \frac{B}{x-3}</math> which becomes

:<math>\displaystyle
1 = A(x-3) + B(x-2)
</math>
after multiplying through by the common denominator of <math>(x-2)(x-3)</math>. If we expand the equation out and find the coefficients of the respective powers of x then:

:<math> \displaystyle
0x + 1 = (A+B)x + (-3A - 2B)
</math>

* From matching the <math>x</math> coefficients, <math>A + B = 0</math> so <math>A = -B</math>.
* From matching the constant coefficients, <math>-3A - 2B = 1</math> which becomes <math>-3(-B) - 2B = 1</math> in using the relation above.

This tells us that <math>B = 1</math> and therefore <math>A = -1</math>.

The integral is easy to evaluate now:

:<math>\begin{align}
\int_0^1 \frac{1}{x^2 - 5x + 6} dx &= \int_0^1 (\frac{1}{x-3} - \frac{1}{x-2}) dx \\
&= [\ln|x-3| - \ln|x-2|]|_0^1 \\
&= (\ln 2 - \ln 1) - (\ln 3 - \ln 2) \\
&= 2 \ln 2 - \ln 3
\end{align}</math>

We used the fact that <math>\ln 1 = 0</math> above.
